He won the event by almost 30 points. Malinin contended that his performance was only about ‚Äú85 percent‚Äù of what he was capable of bringing to the Olympics. He wasn‚Äôt just flexing. The flex came later, on Instagram, when he posted a video of himself in a practice rink successfully performing an unheard-of quad axel‚Äìquad axel combination, to a crashing Babymetal soundtrack. Malinin‚Äôs Instagram feed tends to be a good preview of what to expect from him next. Lately, he has also begun teasing a quintuple jump. Malinin started quietly working toward the quint about two years ago. Lounging on the practice rink‚Äôs sofa, he casually acknowledged that he had already successfully landed one. ‚ÄúIn front of people?‚Äù I asked. ‚ÄúMy parents,‚Äù he said.

item.title: A Surprisingly Humane ‚ÄòSNL‚Äô Sketch About Changing Your Mind
item.description:
Summary: This article highlights a standout sketch from Saturday Night Live's 1,000th episode, featuring featured player Ashley Padilla as a mother tentatively admitting to her children that she is reconsidering her support for Donald Trump. The review praises Padilla‚Äôs physical comedy and the sketch‚Äôs nuanced portrayal of familial political polarization and the vulnerability involved in changing one‚Äôs mind.

Tags: Saturday Night Live,Ashley Padilla,Donald Trump,Television,Alexander Skarsg√•rd


Source: link.theatlantic.com via MAGA‚Äôs war on empathy, by Hillary Rodham Clinton
item.content:encoded:
Summary: This article highlights a standout sketch from Saturday Night Live's 1,000th episode, featuring featured player Ashley Padilla as a mother tentatively admitting to her children that she is reconsidering her support for Donald Trump. The review praises Padilla‚Äôs physical comedy and the sketch‚Äôs nuanced portrayal of familial political polarization and the vulnerability involved in changing one‚Äôs mind.
Ashley Padilla‚Äôs gradual star turn on Saturday Night Live has been thrilling to watch. Since she joined the show as a featured player in 2024, on the cusp of its big 50th anniversary season, Padilla has reliably transformed innocuous-seeming characters‚Äînotably, moms‚Äîinto character studies that pluck at eccentricities lurking just below the surface. In last night‚Äôs episode, Padilla‚Äôs performance as a mother admitting a change of heart in her political views marked one of her strongest roles to date. In a sketch titled ‚ÄúMom Confession,‚Äù Padilla and her husband (played by this week‚Äôs delightfully zany host, Alexander Skarsg√•rd) were about to head to dinner with their four children, who were visiting from afar. As they all got up to leave, Padilla told her children that she first needed to share a ‚Äúshocking‚Äù development with them‚Äîbut wouldn‚Äôt reveal what it was unless they promised not to react. She anxiously did a couple of practice rounds to ensure they wouldn‚Äôt, announcing that she ate bugs and that her butt had fallen off: ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt find it,‚Äù she said sternly. She then revealed her confession in between staccato breaths: ‚ÄúWhat I have to tell you ‚Ä¶ is I may have changed my mind ‚Ä¶ about Trump.‚Äù ‚ÄúMom Confession‚Äù was one of several sketches in the episode that nodded to the latest developments in national news. Although the performance didn‚Äôt explicitly mention ICE‚Äôs brutal tactics in Minneapolis, the show was more frank elsewhere: The cold open featured former cast member Pete Davidson impersonating ‚Äúborder czar‚Äù Tom Homan in his attempt to take the temperature down in the city. ICE came up again in ‚ÄúWeekend Update,‚Äù and in the Marcello Hern√°ndez‚Äìled ‚ÄúImmigrant Dad Talk Show‚Äù sketch, which Hern√°ndez kicked off by addressing ‚Äúall the white people that are sad about the immigrants getting deported.‚Äù But ‚ÄúMom Confession‚Äù imagined how the news cycle might be playing out more intimately in some American homes, where political polarization within families has become a more salient topic since Donald Trump‚Äôs first election in 2016. After Padilla revealed her shifting opinion on the president, her four kids couldn‚Äôt stop themselves from animatedly interjecting. Padilla swiftly unraveled, screaming back, ‚ÄúStop! Do you want this to be real or not?‚Äù As the kids bit their tongues, she continued, vaguely alluding to how recent events had made her reconsider her support: ‚ÄúI feel now ‚Ä¶ like he might be ‚Ä¶ bad for our country.‚Äù When her exasperated children noted that they‚Äôd been saying as much for years, Padilla instantly registered their rebuttal as self-righteousness: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm sorry I‚Äôm late to the perfect party!‚Äù Padilla‚Äôs mannerisms‚Äîand a tightly written script that brought into sharp focus a familiar argument that‚Äôs clearly played out in the family before‚Äîmade this sketch an outstanding bit in last night‚Äôs solid episode, the 1,000th installment of the show. Here, the actor‚Äôs physical-comedy chops brought to life the role of a Trump-supporting mother leery about revealing her evolving views to her seemingly left-leaning children. Padilla nailed her delivery between gulping breaths and stomach clutching, as though doing so was helping her stand up straight. When her children cut in again, the walls went back up. ‚ÄúBye! I take it back,‚Äù she snapped, falling back into a chair, sulking, and twisting her body away from them. Whenever she felt the slightest inkling of criticism burbling up, Padilla lashed out with a smattering of stereotypes about liberal America: ‚ÄúYou think you know everything with your matcha, rapping Hamilton, and your IUDs!‚Äù The sketch exposed why politics can be such tense territory for family members: Few people are willing to admit to a change of heart out of fear of judgment. For those who‚Äôve sat through political arguments with family members of opposing beliefs, it might be hard to imagine outspoken voters being vulnerable with one another in this way. But seeing Padilla pout her way through her confession, while pleading for grace, was its own sort of fantasy. Skarsg√•rd‚Äôs aloof dad supported her through the whole thing, and by the end, her kids apologized for making it so hard for her to talk to them about the topic. In a way, the sketch considered a scenario where families could at least begin talking about politics, rather than stomping away.
